abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment shows unsatisfactory
            project outcomes, unlikely sustainability, and modest
            institutional development impacts, and, likewise, both
            performances by the Bank, and Borrower are rated
            unsatisfactory. Lessons address: 1) the lack of adequate
            attention to regulatory, and sector reform issues, since
            project design focused on coverage, and
            decentralization/strengthening of the autonomous water
            utilities and operating agencies, overlooking important
            structural, sectoral issues which still hinder sector
            development. Instead, had the regulatory framework,
            including pricing and tariffs, and the respective role of
            public institutions and private participation, been resolved
            early on, constrained sector developments could have been
            avoided; 2) the inadequacy of financial policies in the
            allocation of public funds, where the weak enforcement of
            quality services by the National Water Commission (CNA), and
            state agencies, does not provide the incentives for local
            governments to either increase cash generation, or borrow to
            improve services; 3) the lack of credible monitoring
            systems, reinforcing the need for (proven by the justified
            attention the Bank gives to monitoring criteria) measurable
            goals, through established mechanisms, i.e., appropriate
            information systems, and project management reviews, in an
            integrated monitoring, and information system; and, 4) the
            ineffective conditionality; lack of timely action to
            restructure, and adjust operations, and, an inadequate
            dialogue with the new administration. All suggests the Bank
            needs to rethink future support, based on an agreed, broad
            sector policy strategy, setting realistic goals, focused on
            technical assistance needs, in addition to financial
            policies, addressing tariffs, and cost recovery as a key
            structural sector issue.
